page.title: 03HONEYCROOK, HAYDON BRIDGE
page.content: This trout stream flows into the River Tyne.It is in a fine valley which gives shelter to badgers, foxes, squirrels, owls, kingfishers, stoats, weasels and many rabbits.There is a pheasant farm on its banks at Standalone.In the{Nineteenth Century} it was an important{industrial}valley. {Lead ore & Iron ore}were worked, and {stone}was{quarried.}The burn still feeds a reservoir which once supplied water to the{Langley Barony lead mines Near Woodbine Cottage a weir was built and a{water-wheel}installed so that water could be pumped to five farm - houses. The remains of all these workings can still be seen. We have found that many nearby houses were inhabited by miners & masons in the 1851 Census. They now house farmers, a teacher, an Estate agent, a barrister and a gamekeeper.
